title: From Disasters to WoW: Using Web Science to understand and enable 21st century multidimensional networks

I think of this as a perfect storm, the right time to do these things, and the four things is one starts with theories, and by this I'm really talking about social science theories in the social Sciences, we have a terrific understanding now.
Still much to be done, but a very good understanding.
A solid understanding of why we create, maintain, dissolve the kinds of network links we do, and so there is an understanding of the generative mechanisms.

Now we do have the data to test them because of semantic web because of linked data.
Because of Web 2.0 generally.
We have vast amounts of digital traces that we never had previously.

So those are the four takeaways.
We have good theory.
We have good methods.

Times is doing with network data, so a 2 slide, then introduction to networks social networks is.

Why or this person went ahead, not because of what they know, but because of who they know.

And they're trying to shy away from The Who you know, part of it is just deluding ourselves.
The second is this idea called cognitive social networks.
It's not who you know, it's who they think you know.
Each of us have in our mind map of who knows who, and it is on the basis of that map that we are acting.
So that when each of us have a decision about where to go to, we're doing it because we think somebody is well connected.
There's a story that goes back to.
Pitsburgh at the turn of the 19th, 20th century, where was very rich industrialist who had a friend who was not very wealthy and but it was a good friend.
So the friend went to his industrialist wealthy friend and said, you know, I have this great idea for a product that I'm going to make an if only I could get $10,000.

I'm sure I'll be able to make a million out of that and the rich industrialist friend said, you know, I don't want to ruin our friendship by loaning you the money, but this is what I will do tomorrow morning at 9:00 AM.
You and I will walk into the bank together.
And I'll have my arms around you.
And when the banks person sees that I know you, they'll give you the loan because it's not who you know it's who they.
In this case, the bank thinks you know, etc.
So we have to take into account this mental map.

It's particularly important in this virtual age because we are now not able to see who knows who easily because we are hiding behind the Internet and as a result very often normal ways of finding out who is connected to whom are now being clouded by what is happening in the private parts of the of the Internet, etc.

So in many ways, a lot of what I want to talk about today is trying to understand how we answer those four questions and what are the ways in which we can be more effective in answering those kinds of questions.
Through the use of technology.
Here's an example of something that happens at a completely different level from the individual.
So these are structures.
This is John Kelly who is finishing his PhD at Columbia.

Has done this as a network of all the blogs in different languages and what you see out here is the structures of the blogs and the links amongst them actually varies quite dramatically across different languages and across different cultures.
So for example, when you look at the Russian blogosphere, you have a core of blogs in the center and then you have these little splinter ones on the on the periphery of that.
What are those represents?
Those actually represent different communities outside of geographically different communities outside of Moscow and outside of the central part out there, etc.
On the other hand, in the English language blog you see these two clusters on the left and the right, and what do you think those represent?
Political affiliations exactly.
So in the English language the divisions happen based on political affiliations.
In Russia it happens based upon geography and there are different explanations for a lot of these different kinds of explanations in the blogosphere.
So again, the point here being, how do we explain why these different kinds of structures happen?
What are the social drivers that explain why some of these may differ from others?
So more generally, what are the generative mechanisms that explain the emergent structures that are observed in large scale networks?
So I want to start by talking about some of the theories that we can use to understand that.
So in a book that my collaborator Peter Manjhi who is at the.
Southern California and I wrote a few years ago.
What we did was we actually went through a lot of the social networks research literature over the last four five decades.
Ever since Marino began to map those networks in New York City.
And then we looked at this literature to see what are the motivations for why I might want to create a link with someone.
So let's, let's say I want to understand why one of the main reasons is an economic model.
Is the theory of self interest.
I want something that you have.
I want to maximize my individual utility function.
And so, from an economic standpoint, it says that if I want something that John has, then I'm going to get it from John.
And that created network link, which are the only problem with this is John may not necessarily return my calls.
He may not be interested in it, so that this theory works some of the time, but not all of the time.
A second theory is a theory of social and resource exchange.
Which says I want something that John has, but John wants something that I have, so we set up a social exchange and that becomes another way in which to explain a network ties.
So in fact, most market relationships are based on that.
I pay someone money in exchange for products and services.
A third kind of link reason for why we create these network links is something called mutual interest in collective action.
In this case is not that I want anything from Gregory or Gregory wants anything from me, but together we have a better shot.
Of getting something from a third party, right?
So when we come together to do lobby when we come together to do a political movement.
When you come together to set standards?
In those cases, we're not asking for something from each other.
We're working jointly in order to improve our ability to get something from a third party.
Then we go to the 4th side.
So these are fairly rational approaches that we can use here.
On the 4th side, the reason that I may want to create a link with Laura is not because I want anything from Laura.
Laura wants anything from me, but I walked into the room and I see that everyone is well connected to Laura and so I feel.
Oh in that case I should be well connected to Laura as well.
So it is by contagion.
I'm infected by the idea that this is already a well connected person, so how does that work?
Well, this is how you get those kinds of preferential attachment.
Or you get those scale free networks where the rich, those who already are well connected.
Are going to get even more notes connecting to them because other people are going to mimic the actions of those who are already well connected.

There's also an efficiency argument that if I don't know many people in the community and I have to make a connection and I connect to the person who is already well connected in the community, I am now 2 steps removed or one step removed from a lot of other people who this person is connected to.
So that explains why sometimes you create a link with someone because she or he is already well connected.
The next explanation is a much more social, psychological explanation is called the theory of balance.
And what this basically means is I like to be friends with friends of my friends.
Right, and that explains a lot of what happens within these networks.
So for example, if I know Laura Ann Loren OO, there's a greater likelihood that I'm going to become friends with Europe, right?
Because of the friends of a friend, ID etc.
Is this a good thing?
Not necessarily if I'm looking for new and novel information.

If I'm looking for a job, if I'm looking for the next disruptive innovation, I shouldn't be spending my time talking to friends of my friends because friends of my friends have the same kind of information that my friends already have.
I'm much better off talking to people who are not friends of my friends.
Because that's where novel information is going to come into the network, so it represents a psychological desire to have to be friends with friends of friends.
The 4th idea that you all familiar with, but in many cases you may not want that exactly because friends of friends may bring may not bring you novel information.
The next one is a theory of homophily.
So this is of course what we know is birds of a feather flock together.
We like to be with people like ourselves.
So if I were to look in this room, I see that there are even just based on sort of physical attributes.
I can see.
Oh, there are a bunch of Asians sitting together, for example, right?
Or women who sit together etc.
But I can also go beyond that and look at disciplines and say oh people who came from the same country are sitting together or people who are from the same subarea sitting together, etc.
Why is that?
Why is it that we like to talk to people like ourselves?
We do that because we share a common language.
We share a common.
Background so we have similarities that we can use to understand each other.
That's the good news.
That's also the bad news, because if we continue to be with people like ourselves and talk to people like ourselves when we don't have the opportunity to be challenged about our basic assumptions.
And so a lot of really interesting innovation comes when you have people from different areas coming together rather than people who are similar to one another.
So there's a lot of research that's been done in groups that shows that people that groups which are very homopholis, that is, people.

Are very similar to each other that these groups tend to be very satisfied with the work they do, they just don't tend to be very creative as compared to heterogeneous groups where some of the groups can be extremely creative.

They often tend to be not very satisfied because there's a lot of hard work involved in bringing people together and getting them to engage, but also, there's very great likelihood that sometimes those groups will fail miserably, so the variance and creativity of heterogeneous groups is quite high in that case.
The next one I touch on here is theories of proximity.
So what is theory approximately?
It says that you will talk to people who are close by to you, right?
People in the same city in the same office in the same building, etc.
And you might ask yourself that in this day and age now with all the electronic technologies we have, how important is proximity?
The Economist magazine.
When one of my favorite magazines said had a cover story a few years ago, they said the death of distance distance doesn't matter anymore.
We can talk to anyone, anywhere.
I'll give you a preview to say that some of the results that I'm going to show you based on some of our large virtual worlds analysis on the web shows that distance matters more than ever before.
That, in fact, today and that we are using the technology is not as a replacement for face to face communication, but in fact to support face to face communication.
That increasingly we have scenarios where if you think about it, the single largest application of email is to set up face to face meetings.
So we're using the technology to actually facilitate the kind of physical interaction.
If some of many of you I'm assuming are on things like Skype or I am, etc, which have a little buddy list, think about the buddy list that you have.
When I was at University of Illinois before moving to Northwestern, we did a study of the students buddy lists and the Geo locations of these people.
And what did we find we found?
That if you think that distance doesn't matter, it should be a uniform distribution that the people on your buddy list.
The people you talked to electronically should be at, you know, equal likelihood of being at any distance.
But in fact, what we find is that it shows somewhat of a power law distribution where a large majority of the people on your on your buddy lists are actually people who are really close by to you.
And then it trails off.
You do have some connections with people far away.
In some cases it even spikes up a little bit, but by and large the people on your buddy lists.
Are people who are really close by, so think about that in your own context.
Why is that?
Well, because these are the people.
For example, in my situation, my entire lab is part of my Skype list, right?
And these are all people in the same floor as me.
The same thing we found.

The students would be in the same in the students who had on their bodies would be on the same building, the same floor, sometimes in the same room that they are using the Skype's away just to coordinate and stay in touch with each other, etc.
So I would argue that proximity matters even more today than it does before before going to the next slide, I should say that.

In terms of structure, is the nice thing about what we just talked about your in terms of the theories is that each of these verbal descriptions of theories that we have here is also something that Maps onto a particular map out in terms of network configurations.

Which means that if people are operating on the basis of theories of self interest, there is a certain structural signature that is more likely to be found in the data than if they were operating save basis of exchange where you'd see a different structural signature or balance where you see a third one.
Our collective action in mutual interest, where you'd see a 4th one.
Some links are more likely to happen that those are marked with a positive sign.
Some are less likely to happen, those are marked with a negative signs.

This makes the theoretical stuff very interesting, because now all of a sudden what you can do is to say you can give me a messy network, apply to spaghetti that looks like a network that looks like a plate of spaghetti, and I can now begin to extract from it.
Understanding of what motivates network links being created in there are the links being created based on social exchange?
Are they being created based on the self interest?
To what extent is it based on homophily and so on and so forth.

And in fact, this is where some of the new statistical methods that are being applied in network science come in, that in this case what we have is there's a particular set of theories called P star or expert.

Random graph models, and I think of this as a statistical MRI because what it does is it looks at these networks and deserves the extent to which those structural signatures that that are connected to a theory are more likely to be found than in a random network.

'cause any random network will have some other structural signatures, but we're trying to understand is the likelihood of these structural signatures to be much larger than what you would expect in a random networks on the basis of that, and you will see some results of this set later on that what you're really saying is you can look at a network.
Web and say this network is being driven say 15% by self interest 22% by social exchange 15% by balance and so on and so forth.
I caricature a little bit but that's the basic idea that you're able to understand.
What is the dynamics?
What are driving these kind?
Networks etc.
So of course, not all theories are going to be true for any organizational setting.
In some cases, the goal of the network maybe to explore new ideas.
In some cases it may be to exploit existing resources you already have what it takes, and you're trying to see if you can make it better.
The exploration is important when you're looking for disruptive innovations and new idea exploitation is more important when you are trying to get incremental innovation.
That is, you're trying to make something cheaper or faster, etc.
Sometimes the network goes is mobilizing.
We're trying to come together in order to engage in some collective action.

Sometimes it's bonding for those of you who are familiar with World of Warcraft, there was an interesting article that Joi Ito wrote in, which he said that people are playing these games, not necessarily for competition.
They're playing these games just to build bonds and to build trust with each other.
So much so that they argue that these games that people are playing now on the web.
In many cases, it's like the 21st century version of golf where people play golf.

Some people play golf competition, but the majority of people are playing golf in order to build bonds and to build friendship into build, trust, and the same thing can be said for some of these games.
And then finally we have a category called swarming and that says a network is in place, but it comes together rapidly.
For a short period of time in order to to engage in some kind of swarm behavior.
So this would be examples of emergency response scenarios where the network stays still for the most part quickly has to come together for a short period of time and then disband again.
So these are the kinds of theories that so not all theories are going to be useful for all kinds of goals.

Some theories are going to be more useful depending on what goals the community is trying to engage in and what this allows us to do then is to say if we want to build a network that is particularly good for exploration.
What kinds of incentives should we provide our people?
Which kind of theoretical motivations are more likely to make that network effective?
So this is now taking the ideas of network science and moving it into what could be called as net.
Engineering if you may.
So one of the things that the rest of the of the presentation I'm just going to go through some empirical examples of what we have done now in our lab.
So this is my lab science of networks and communities.

It's called Sonic, and so these are some of the applications that we're looking at and where we're looking at how networks are created on the top left is a set of applications that are called sampling science applications.
These are basically groups of scientists and engineers who are coming together to engage in some kind of research or issues of that kind, or in terms of.
Rapid response, etc.
So there's a lot of interest in how these networks come together.
I'll have a slight later on that shows that most of the time our collaborations are actually not very successful.
Not very special either.
Geographically distributed collaborations and if they are across disciplines.
However, when they are successful they are extremely successful.
And if you look at the web of science, the most most highly popular articles are those that are written by teams of people across disciplines.
And across geography, so clearly there is a paradox here.
In some cases we are succeeding in doing it very well, but in the vast majority of cases we're not.
So we're really interested in what sometimes gets referred to as team science.
How can we help build better collaborations?
Even putting the right teams?
Think of this is how do we use a love Getty or a sniff to build the best kind of team together to start with a research project.
We also have some applications in business where we're looking at places like communities of practice and firms like Procter and Gamble.
And how these communities of practice come together and what makes them more successful than in other cases?

I'll spend a lot of time talking about entertainment applications where I'll talk a little bit about Second Life as well as from EverQuest 2, which is a game like World of Warcraft that is owned by Sony.

And finally, I will not talk very much, but we also in a lab look at societal justice applications, and this is areas where we're looking, for example, at low income communities in the city of Chicago and how they networks are forming to respond to climate change issues, etc.
Of course, the core research in all of these areas is to understand what are the sociotechnical drivers for creating and sustaining these different.
Kinds of communities.
One of the important things, though, that we have not.
Even spoken much about so far is that the networks we've talked about mostly so far on networks that are made up of either people or in one case blogs.
But today we are living in what I would call a multidimensional network, and that is a network with some of the nodes are people.
Some of the nodes are documents.
Some of the nodes are tags or concepts.
Some of the nodes are analytic tools etc.
And so one of the areas where we need to do more theorizing and understanding is how do we think of that larger network.

Southern California and I wrote a few years ago.
What we did was we actually went through a lot of the social networks research literature over the last four five decades.
Ever since Marino began to map those networks in New York City.
And then we looked at this literature to see what are the motivations for why I might want to create a link with someone.
So let's, let's say I want to understand why one of the main reasons is an economic model.
Is the theory of self interest.
I want something that you have.
I want to maximize my individual utility function.
And so, from an economic standpoint, it says that if I want something that John has, then I'm going to get it from John.
And that created network link, which are the only problem with this is John may not necessarily return my calls.
He may not be interested in it, so that this theory works some of the time, but not all of the time.
A second theory is a theory of social and resource exchange.
Which says I want something that John has, but John wants something that I have, so we set up a social exchange and that becomes another way in which to explain a network ties.
So in fact, most market relationships are based on that.
I pay someone money in exchange for products and services.
A third kind of link reason for why we create these network links is something called mutual interest in collective action.
In this case is not that I want anything from Gregory or Gregory wants anything from me, but together we have a better shot.
Of getting something from a third party, right?
So when we come together to do lobby when we come together to do a political movement.
When you come together to set standards?
In those cases, we're not asking for something from each other.
We're working jointly in order to improve our ability to get something from a third party.
Then we go to the 4th side.
So these are fairly rational approaches that we can use here.
On the 4th side, the reason that I may want to create a link with Laura is not because I want anything from Laura.
Laura wants anything from me, but I walked into the room and I see that everyone is well connected to Laura and so I feel.
Oh in that case I should be well connected to Laura as well.
So it is by contagion.
I'm infected by the idea that this is already a well connected person, so how does that work?
Well, this is how you get those kinds of preferential attachment.
Or you get those scale free networks where the rich, those who already are well connected.
Are going to get even more notes connecting to them because other people are going to mimic the actions of those who are already well connected.

There's also an efficiency argument that if I don't know many people in the community and I have to make a connection and I connect to the person who is already well connected in the community, I am now 2 steps removed or one step removed from a lot of other people who this person is connected to.
So that explains why sometimes you create a link with someone because she or he is already well connected.
The next explanation is a much more social, psychological explanation is called the theory of balance.
And what this basically means is I like to be friends with friends of my friends.
Right, and that explains a lot of what happens within these networks.
So for example, if I know Laura Ann Loren OO, there's a greater likelihood that I'm going to become friends with Europe, right?
Because of the friends of a friend, ID etc.
Is this a good thing?
Not necessarily if I'm looking for new and novel information.

If I'm looking for a job, if I'm looking for the next disruptive innovation, I shouldn't be spending my time talking to friends of my friends because friends of my friends have the same kind of information that my friends already have.
I'm much better off talking to people who are not friends of my friends.
Because that's where novel information is going to come into the network, so it represents a psychological desire to have to be friends with friends of friends.
The 4th idea that you all familiar with, but in many cases you may not want that exactly because friends of friends may bring may not bring you novel information.
The next one is a theory of homophily.
So this is of course what we know is birds of a feather flock together.
We like to be with people like ourselves.

I can see.

Why is that?
Why is it that we like to talk to people like ourselves?
We do that because we share a common language.
We share a common.
Background so we have similarities that we can use to understand each other.
That's the good news.
That's also the bad news, because if we continue to be with people like ourselves and talk to people like ourselves when we don't have the opportunity to be challenged about our basic assumptions.
And so a lot of really interesting innovation comes when you have people from different areas coming together rather than people who are similar to one another.
So there's a lot of research that's been done in groups that shows that people that groups which are very homopholis, that is, people.

Are very similar to each other that these groups tend to be very satisfied with the work they do, they just don't tend to be very creative as compared to heterogeneous groups where some of the groups can be extremely creative.

They often tend to be not very satisfied because there's a lot of hard work involved in bringing people together and getting them to engage, but also, there's very great likelihood that sometimes those groups will fail miserably, so the variance and creativity of heterogeneous groups is quite high in that case.

Networks etc.
So of course, not all theories are going to be true for any organizational setting.
In some cases, the goal of the network maybe to explore new ideas.
In some cases it may be to exploit existing resources you already have what it takes, and you're trying to see if you can make it better.
The exploration is important when you're looking for disruptive innovations and new idea exploitation is more important when you are trying to get incremental innovation.
That is, you're trying to make something cheaper or faster, etc.
Sometimes the network goes is mobilizing.
We're trying to come together in order to engage in some collective action.

Sometimes it's bonding for those of you who are familiar with World of Warcraft, there was an interesting article that Joi Ito wrote in, which he said that people are playing these games, not necessarily for competition.
They're playing these games just to build bonds and to build trust with each other.
So much so that they argue that these games that people are playing now on the web.
In many cases, it's like the 21st century version of golf where people play golf.

Some people play golf competition, but the majority of people are playing golf in order to build bonds and to build friendship into build, trust, and the same thing can be said for some of these games.
And then finally we have a category called swarming and that says a network is in place, but it comes together rapidly.
For a short period of time in order to to engage in some kind of swarm behavior.
So this would be examples of emergency response scenarios where the network stays still for the most part quickly has to come together for a short period of time and then disband again.
So these are the kinds of theories that so not all theories are going to be useful for all kinds of goals.

Some theories are going to be more useful depending on what goals the community is trying to engage in and what this allows us to do then is to say if we want to build a network that is particularly good for exploration.
What kinds of incentives should we provide our people?
Which kind of theoretical motivations are more likely to make that network effective?
So this is now taking the ideas of network science and moving it into what could be called as net.

Even spoken much about so far is that the networks we've talked about mostly so far on networks that are made up of either people or in one case blogs.
But today we are living in what I would call a multidimensional network, and that is a network with some of the nodes are people.
Some of the nodes are documents.
Some of the nodes are tags or concepts.
Some of the nodes are analytic tools etc.
And so one of the areas where we need to do more theorizing and understanding is how do we think of that larger network.
So think of this as a fishnet where I can pick up a node and that node is a person, but I want to see.
All the documents, all the datasets, all the analytic tools that are connected to this particular person.
Or Conversely I can pick up a concept or A tag and say show me the people, the documents, the datasets that are associated with this particular tag, and I can ask for one more step goes beyond that.
And say don't only show me those that are connected to this one concept.
